elements.content: Three new copper compounds, Cu2[C12H8N2]2[C28H20S4O16][H2O]11.9 (1), Cu2[C12H8N2]3[C28H20S4O16][H2O]5 (2), and Cu2[C12H8N2]4[C24H12S8O16][H2O]10.5 (3), were hydrothermally synthesized and structurally determined by X-ray diffraction and TG-DTA analyses. Interestingly, Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized in a one-pot reaction. Complexes 1 and 3 contain capsule units, which are further assembled into three-dimensional (3-D) architectures with α-Po-related topology by π−π stacking and/or hydrogen-bonding interactions. In compound 2, the zigzag chains are bridged into a 2-D 63 or 44 net by π−π stacking interactions, which are stacked further into a 3-D supramolecular topology by hydrogen-bonding interactions. It is obvious that the weak intramolecular/intermolecular interactions play an important role in the formation of supramolecular networks, especially in linking low-dimensional entities into high-dimensional supramolecular frameworks. In these complexes (together with two previous compounds we prepared at room temperature), p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene (C4AS) and p-sulfonatothiacalix[4]arene (TC4AS) ligands assuming cone shape bond to the copper cations in different ways which facilitate the formation of different topologies. Compounds 1−3 exhibit blue emission in the solid state at room temperature and their thermal properties are examined.

The weak intramolecular/intermolecular interactions and the different coordination environment of calixarenes led to the formation of different topologies

elements.content: Water-soluble calix[n]arenes (n = 4−8), some macrocyclic structures containing several phenol rings which are some inherent chromophore and ready for various chemical modification, have been widely investigated and are becoming increasingly important in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering. p-Sulfonatocalix[4]arene (C4AS, Scheme ) has gained much more attention among the water-soluble calix[4]arenes (CAS), and a variety of complexes of C4AS have been reported with main group, transition metal or lanthanide species, and with additional organic supramolecular building components. For instance, many “Russian dolls” or “molecular capsules”, “ferris wheels”, hydrogen bonded polymers, and 2-D coordination polymers have been reported of included crown ether or aza macrocycle and metal cations as the guests. Amino acids have also been reported to be encapsuled in the molecular capsules. However, inclusion compounds of C4AS concerning 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) are rarely reported. Raston et al. reported two nickel/Phen/C4AS inclusion complexes prepared by mechanochemistry. Liu et al. studied the factors governing the formation of capsules in the Phen/C4AS complexes and synthesized some transition metal/Phen/C4AS complexes. Recently, our group prepared two copper/Phen/C4AS complexes with infinite 1-D channels at different pH values and a zinc/Phen/C4AS supramolecular complex bridged by novel (H2O)10 water clusters under hydrothermal conditions. Comparatively, another structurally related a water-soluble sulfur-bridged calix[4]arene, p-sulfonatothiacalix[4]arene (TC4AS), which can bond metal cations not only at the upper and lower rims but also by the bridging sulfur atoms, is still not used widely for the construction of coordination networks. As an extension of our previous investigation on the metal/Phen/CAS system, three novel copper compounds, Cu2[C12H8N2]2[C28H20S4O16][H2O]11.9 (1), Cu2[C12H8N2]3[C28H20S4O16][H2O]5 (2) and Cu2[C12H8N2]4[C24H12S8O16][H2O]10.5 (3), were obtained by hydrothermal syntheses. In these three complexes, Phen acts as a terminal ligand, and the CAS molecules are bonded to copper cations in various coordination modes, which leads to the formation of different three-dimensional (3-D) Cu(II) supramolecular complexes 1−3.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Water-soluble calix[n]arenes (n = 4-8), some macrocyclic structures containing several phenol rings which are some inherent chromophore and ready for various chemical modification, have been widely investigated and are becoming increasingly important in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering. p-Sulfonatocalix[4]arene (C4AS, Scheme ) has gained much more attention among the water-soluble calix[4]arenes (CAS), and a variety of complexes of C4AS have been reported with main group, transition metal or lanthanide species, and with additional organic supramolecular building components. For instance, many "Russian dolls" or "molecular capsules", "ferris wheels", hydrogen bonded polymers, and 2-D coordination polymers have been reported of included crown ether or aza macrocycle and metal cations as the guests. Amino acids have also been reported to be encapsuled in the molecular capsules. However, inclusion compounds of C4AS concerning 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) are rarely reported. Raston et al. reported two nickel/Phen/C4AS inclusion complexes prepared by mechanochemistry. Liu et al. studied the factors governing the formation of capsules in the Phen/C4AS complexes and synthesized some transition metal/Phen/C4AS complexes. Recently, our group prepared two copper/Phen/C4AS complexes with infinite 1-D channels at different pH values and a zinc/Phen/C4AS supramolecular complex bridged by novel (H2O)10 water clusters under hydrothermal conditions. Comparatively, another structurally related a water-soluble sulfur-bridged calix[4]arene, p-sulfonatothiacalix[4]arene (TC4AS), which can bond metal cations not only at the upper and lower rims but also by the bridging sulfur atoms, is still not used widely for the construction of coordination networks. As an extension of our previous investigation on the metal/Phen/CAS system, three novel copper compounds, Cu2[C12H8N2]2[C28H20S4O16][H2O]11.9 (1), Cu2[C12H8N2]3[C28H20S4O16][H2O]5 (2) and Cu2[C12H8N2]4[C24H12S8O16][H2O]10.5 (3), were obtained by hydrothermal syntheses. In these three complexes, Phen acts as a terminal ligand, and the CAS molecules are bonded to copper cations in various coordination modes, which leads to the formation of different three-dimensional (3-D) Cu(II) supramolecular complexes 1-3.

C4AS and TC4AS were synthesized according to the literature, and other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-4500 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. TG/DTA measurements were performed on a SDT 2960 simultaneous DSC−TGA instrument (TA instruments).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

C4AS and TC4AS were synthesized according to the literature, and other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Photoluminescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-4500 spectrophotometer with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. TG/DTA measurements were performed on a SDT 2960 simultaneous DSC-TGA instrument (TA instruments).

elements.content: A suspension of CuCl2 (0.2 mmol), Phen (0.2 mmol), and C4AS (0.1 mmol) in water (10 mL) was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (20 mL) and heated to 130 °C in 100 min. The autoclave was kept at 130 °C for 3 days and then slowly cooled to 20 °C at about 4 °C/h. Green prism single crystals of 1 and blue block single crystals of 2 were carefully separated under a microscope and collected for X-ray diffraction determination and other measurements. Yield: ∼10% for 1 and 25% for 2 with respect to calixarene.

elements.content: The X-ray intensity data for compounds 1−3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystal structure was solved by means of direct methods and refined employing full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXTL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms except some disordered water molecules were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. All the crystal data and structure refinement details for these three compounds are given in Table . Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC reference numbers 650048, 672458, and 672459 for compounds 1−3, respectively.

X-ray Crystallography

The X-ray intensity data for compounds 1-3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystal structure was solved by means of direct methods and refined employing full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXTL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms except some disordered water molecules were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. All the crystal data and structure refinement details for these three compounds are given in Table . Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC reference numbers 650048, 672458, and 672459 for compounds 1-3, respectively.

Complexes 1−3 were synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions, and their formations were governed by the reaction conditions such as pH value and the reactant molar ratio. Compounds 1 and 2 cocrystallized in a one-pot synthesis, and the attempt to prepare pure 1 or 2 in one reactor failed. The successful isolation of compounds 1 and 2 depends on the exploitation of hydrothermal techniques at a pH value of ca. 2.0 (before and after reaction). The introduction of lanthanide elements (with the aim to get mixed-metal compounds) does not affect the formation of 1 and 2. No suitable crystals were obtained with the same components at room temperature unless the mixture pH was adjusted to ca. 4.5 (for Cu3[C12H8N2]3[C28H19S4O16]Cl[H2O]17.6 (4) or 2.5 (for Cu2[C12H8N2][C28H20S4O16][H2O]23.5 (5)) together with the changed reactant ratios as reported previously. CuCl was used for the synthesis of compound 3 instead of CuCl2 because Cu2+ might oxidate TC4AS under acidic conditions. Otherwise, brown participate will form when CuCl2 and TC4AS were mixed in the molar ratio of 1:1. Furthermore, no suitable crystals can be found with a molar ratio of CuCl and TC4AS of >2:1. Fortunately, X-ray-quality crystals of 1−3 were acquired after many trials; thus, the systematic investigations of their photoluminescence and thermal properties could be carried out.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Complexes 1-3 were synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions, and their formations were governed by the reaction conditions such as pH value and the reactant molar ratio. Compounds 1 and 2 cocrystallized in a one-pot synthesis, and the attempt to prepare pure 1 or 2 in one reactor failed. The successful isolation of compounds 1 and 2 depends on the exploitation of hydrothermal techniques at a pH value of ca. 2.0 (before and after reaction). The introduction of lanthanide elements (with the aim to get mixed-metal compounds) does not affect the formation of 1 and 2. No suitable crystals were obtained with the same components at room temperature unless the mixture pH was adjusted to ca. 4.5 (for Cu3[C12H8N2]3[C28H19S4O16]Cl[H2O]17.6 (4) or 2.5 (for Cu2[C12H8N2][C28H20S4O16][H2O]23.5 (5)) together with the changed reactant ratios as reported previously. CuCl was used for the synthesis of compound 3 instead of CuCl2 because Cu2+ might oxidate TC4AS under acidic conditions. Otherwise, brown participate will form when CuCl2 and TC4AS were mixed in the molar ratio of 1:1. Furthermore, no suitable crystals can be found with a molar ratio of CuCl and TC4AS of >2:1. Fortunately, X-ray-quality crystals of 1-3 were acquired after many trials; thus, the systematic investigations of their photoluminescence and thermal properties could be carried out.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic system with space group P21/c and an asymmetric unit contains two six-coordinated Cu atoms. As shown in Figure a, Cu(1) atom is coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms (with the distances Cu(1)−O(5) = 2.224(5) Å and Cu(1)−O(10) = 2.788(7) Å) of two C4AS ligands, two water molecules, and two nitrogen atoms from one Phen ligand. Cu(2) stands outside of the C4AS cavity and adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating one Phen ligand (two nitrogen atoms), one sulfonate oxygen atom (bond distance: Cu(2)−O(14) = 2.408(5) Å) of C4AS ligand, and three coordinated water molecules (the longest bond: Cu(2)−O(21) = 2.335(6) Å). Both Cu(1) and Cu(2) are weakly coordinated by two oxygen atoms due to a strong Jahn−Teller effect. Except for the weakly coordinated atoms, all the other atoms bond to the copper atoms with distances in the range from 1.960(6) to 2.035(6) Å. Two C4AS ligands in cone conformation are located face-to-face and bridged by two Cu(1) atoms to form a closed capsule, and then a tetranuclear copper unit forms.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structure. Cu2[C12H8N2]2[C28H20S4O16][H2O]11.9 (1)

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic system with space group P21/c and an asymmetric unit contains two six-coordinated Cu atoms. As shown in Figure a, Cu(1) atom is coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms (with the distances Cu(1)-O(5) = 2.224(5) Å and Cu(1)-O(10) = 2.788(7) Å) of two C4AS ligands, two water molecules, and two nitrogen atoms from one Phen ligand. Cu(2) stands outside of the C4AS cavity and adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating one Phen ligand (two nitrogen atoms), one sulfonate oxygen atom (bond distance: Cu(2)-O(14) = 2.408(5) Å) of C4AS ligand, and three coordinated water molecules (the longest bond: Cu(2)-O(21) = 2.335(6) Å). Both Cu(1) and Cu(2) are weakly coordinated by two oxygen atoms due to a strong Jahn-Teller effect. Except for the weakly coordinated atoms, all the other atoms bond to the copper atoms with distances in the range from 1.960(6) to 2.035(6) Å. Two C4AS ligands in cone conformation are located face-to-face and bridged by two Cu(1) atoms to form a closed capsule, and then a tetranuclear copper unit forms.

elements.content: The 3-D supramolecular structure can be best described as follows: the tetranuclear units are interconnected to form a 2-D layer via hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table -1) and π−π stacking interactions between aromatic groups of C4AS ligands (with face-to-face distance of ca. 3.492 Å) (Figure b, interaction A), and all the layers are linked by O−H···O bonding (interaction B) into a 3-D supramolecular framework (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: The 3-D supramolecular structure can be best described as follows: the tetranuclear units are interconnected to form a 2-D layer via hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table -1) and π-π stacking interactions between aromatic groups of C4AS ligands (with face-to-face distance of ca. 3.492 Å) (Figure b, interaction A), and all the layers are linked by O-H⋅⋅⋅O bonding (interaction B) into a 3-D supramolecular framework (Figure c).

elements.content: A better insight into the structures of supramolecular compounds can be obtained by reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker reference nets known as the topological approach. As mentioned above, if the tetranuclear Cu units are thought of as nodes and the supramolecular interactions as spacers (16.309 Å and 15.321 Å for A and B respectively), the 2-D layer can be simplified as a gridlike net (44 net) which is further stacked into an α-Po-related topology as shown in Figure d.

As mentioned above, if the tetranuclear Cu units are thought of as nodes and the supramolecular interactions as spacers (16.309 Å and 15.321 Å for A and B respectively), the 2-D layer can be simplified as a gridlike net (44 net) which is further stacked into an α-Po-related topology as shown in Figure d.

elements.content: Compound 2 also crystallizes in a monoclinic system with the same space group P21/c as compound 1, which is different from the previously reported samples 4 and 5 obtained at room temperature. Furthermore, compound 2 contains a 1-D zigzag polynuclear coordination chain whereas compounds 1, 4, and 5 possess tetra-, tri-, and dinuclear units, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Cu2[C12H8N2]3[C28H20S4O16][H2O] (2)

Compound 2 also crystallizes in a monoclinic system with the same space group P21/c as compound 1, which is different from the previously reported samples 4 and 5 obtained at room temperature. Furthermore, compound 2 contains a 1-D zigzag polynuclear coordination chain whereas compounds 1, 4, and 5 possess tetra-, tri-, and dinuclear units, respectively.

elements.content: There are two crystallographically independent Cu(II) centers, five-coordinated Cu(1) and six-coordinated Cu(2), in each asymmtric unit of 2 (Figure a). Cu(1) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N(1), N(2)) of a chelating Phen ligand, two sulfonate oxygen atoms (O(12), O(16)) of two C4AS molecules, and one water molecule (O(17)) to furnish a distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. It should be noted that O(16) from a sulfonate group bonds to Cu(1) with the Cu−O distance of 2.211(3) Å, which is a little longer than the typical distance but can be thought of as coordination. The six-coordinated Cu(2) center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to four nitrogen atoms (N(3)−N(6)) of two chelating Phen ligands, one sulfonate oxygen atom (O(14)), and one water molecule (O(18)). The bond lengths and angles concerned Cu(2) are similar to those of Cu(1) and Cu(2) in 1 except the longer bonds Cu(2)−N(6) (2.335(6) Å) and Cu(2)−O(14) (2.791(4) Å), which can also attribute to Jahn−Teller effect. The nearest C4AS ligands in up−down arrangement are bridged by the Cu(1) atom into some zigzag chains (Figure b).

Cu(1) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N(1), N(2)) of a chelating Phen ligand, two sulfonate oxygen atoms (O(12), O(16)) of two C4AS molecules, and one water molecule (O(17)) to furnish a distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. It should be noted that O(16) from a sulfonate group bonds to Cu(1) with the Cu-O distance of 2.211(3) Å, which is a little longer than the typical distance but can be thought of as coordination. The six-coordinated Cu(2) center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to four nitrogen atoms (N(3)-N(6)) of two chelating Phen ligands, one sulfonate oxygen atom (O(14)), and one water molecule (O(18)). The bond lengths and angles concerned Cu(2) are similar to those of Cu(1) and Cu(2) in 1 except the longer bonds Cu(2)-N(6) (2.335(6) Å) and Cu(2)-O(14) (2.791(4) Å), which can also attribute to Jahn-Teller effect. The nearest C4AS ligands in up-down arrangement are bridged by the Cu(1) atom into some zigzag chains (Figure b).

elements.content: The adjacent zigzag chains are packed through π···π stacking interactions between aromatic groups of phen ligands (face-to-face distance of ca. 3.317 Å, interaction A; 3.463 Å, interaction B) into 2-D networks (Figure b). Furthermore, along another direction, the 2-D networks are ultimately extended into a 3-D supramolecular structure through interlayer O−H···O and C−H···O bonds (see Table -2 and Figure c, interaction C). Interestingly, if the dinuclear units are considered as nodes, the zigzag chains stacking with interaction A (spacers, 17.011 Å) exhibit a 2-D hexagon net (63 net) while their packing with interaction B (spacers, 11.299 Å) shows a 2-D gridlike structure (44 net). Both kinds of layers look like wavelike planes. Both kinds of 2-D layers are finally linked by hydrogen-bonding interactions (spacers, 16.394 Å) into 3-D frameworks; however, the final 3-D topologies are not the same (shown in Figure d).

In four compounds (1, 2, 4 and 5), all the copper cations are coordinated by the Phen molecules acting as the terminal ligands in a typically chelating mode (Scheme f), which is unfavorable for the formation of high dimensional coordination polymers, whereas the copper atoms can bridge the adjacent C4AS molecules within one bilayer or two adjacent bilayers into infinite chains. It is to be pointed out that, though all the C4AS ligands coordinated to copper ions exhibit cone conformation, the coordination and the pinch of C4AS are quite different in compounds 1, 2, 4 and 5 as shown in Scheme a−d. The C4AS ligand bonds to three Cu ions with three sulfonate groups in 1 and with the same one in 2 whereas in compound 5 two Cu ions coordinate to two adjacent sulfonate groups. Differently, the calixarene in 4 is bonded to three Cu ions with two opposite sulfonate groups (one bonded to one Cu ion and the other with two Cu ions). Moreover, in structure 1, the trans S···S distances of C4AS are of 8.940 Å and 12.691 Å (the distance between two oppositely oriented sulfonate groups), and the dihedral angles between the opposite aromatic rings are 71.919° and 45.044°. The corresponding distances in 2 (8.916 Å and 11.420 Å) are similar to those in 1 while the dihedral angles (84.077° and 47.451°) are quite different. With the previous compounds 4 and 5 taken into account, the trans S···S distances are located in the range from 8.940 Å to 12.691 Å and the dihedral angles in the range from 45.044° to 84.077°, which indicates the different pinch of C4AS. The biggest difference between two dihedral angles in 2 means the greatest pinch of calixarene in 2. The biggest difference between two trans S···S distances in 1 might be due to the enlargement of the cavity of calixarene because of the smaller dihedral angle difference in 1 than in 2. That means that the coordination environment and the host−guest interactions might be important for the conformation of the calixarene molecules.

elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination of CAS and Phen in Compounds 1-5

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in a triclinic system, and the structure has been solved in the space group P1̅. There are two independent copper-Phen cations in an asymmetric unit, five-coordinated Cu(1) and six-coordinated Cu(2). Cu(1) atom bonded to two Phen molecules and one sulfonate oxygen atom perches outside the TC4AS cavity while Cu(2) is coordinated by two Phen ligands and two water molecules. The TC4AS molecules exhibit a pinched cone conformation with C 2v symmetry with trans S···S distances being 12.217 Å and 8.488 Å, and dihedral angles being 86.220° and 37.631° (Figure a). Comparing with those dihedral angles of C4AS in 1, 2, 4 and 5, one can find that the dihedral angle differences of TC4AS in 3 are the biggest, which indicates that TC4AS (Scheme e) pinches to a greater extent than C4AS. The greater pinch of TC4AS might be due to the more flexible sulfur linker. In Figure b, one of the Phen molecules bonded to Cu(2) is penetrated into the cavity of TC4AS and forms C−H···π stacking interactions with the TC4AS (Phen heterocyclic C−H···π calixarene ring: 3.664 Å and 3.871 Å). The other Phen molecule coordinated to Cu(2) forms C−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions (C(51)···O(7): 3.309(9) Å), and π···π stacking interactions with the symmetric one and the Phen molecules bonded to Cu(1) (ca.3.344 Å and 3.376 Å, respectively). A tetranuclear capsule forms with TC4AS ligands in face-to-face arrangement.

Cu2[C12H8N2]4[C24H12S8O16][H2O]10.5 (3)

Compound 3 crystallizes in a triclinic system, and the structure has been solved in the space group P1̅. There are two independent copper-Phen cations in an asymmetric unit, five-coordinated Cu(1) and six-coordinated Cu(2). Cu(1) atom bonded to two Phen molecules and one sulfonate oxygen atom perches outside the TC4AS cavity while Cu(2) is coordinated by two Phen ligands and two water molecules. The TC4AS molecules exhibit a pinched cone conformation with C 2v  symmetry with trans S⋅⋅⋅S distances being 12.217 Å and 8.488 Å, and dihedral angles being 86.220° and 37.631° (Figure a). Comparing with those dihedral angles of C4AS in 1, 2, 4 and 5, one can find that the dihedral angle differences of TC4AS in 3 are the biggest, which indicates that TC4AS (Scheme e) pinches to a greater extent than C4AS. The greater pinch of TC4AS might be due to the more flexible sulfur linker. In Figure b, one of the Phen molecules bonded to Cu(2) is penetrated into the cavity of TC4AS and forms C-H⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions with the TC4AS (Phen heterocyclic C-H⋅⋅⋅π calixarene ring: 3.664 Å and 3.871 Å). The other Phen molecule coordinated to Cu(2) forms C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions (C(51)⋅⋅⋅O(7): 3.309(9) Å), and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions with the symmetric one and the Phen molecules bonded to Cu(1) (ca.3.344 Å and 3.376 Å, respectively). A tetranuclear capsule forms with TC4AS ligands in face-to-face arrangement.

elements.content: Two adjacent parallel tetranuclear capsules are interconnected into 2-D sheet by face-to-face π···π stacking interactions between the aromatic ring of TC4AS (ca. 3.332 Å, interaction A), and interactions between TC4AS and Phen ligands bonded to Cu(1) (ca. 3.419 Å and 3.483 Å, interaction B) (Figure c). The 3-D extended structure of 3 is constructed by the stacking of the layers along the c axis via π···π stacking interactions between the aromatic ring of Phen ligands coordinated to Cu(2) (ca. 3.290 Å, interaction C). Interactions A and B (spacers, 26.355 Å and 14.156 Å, respectively) link the tetranuclear nodes into a gridlike layered network (44 net), and interaction C (spacers, 15.063 Å) bridges the 2-D layer into a compressed α-Po-related topology, which is similar to that of 1 (Figure d).

Interactions A and B (spacers, 26.355 Å and 14.156 Å, respectively) link the tetranuclear nodes into a gridlike layered network (44 net), and interaction C (spacers, 15.063 Å) bridges the 2-D layer into a compressed α-Po-related topology, which is similar to that of 1 (Figure d).

elements.content: The TGA curves of the title compounds 1−3 are similar, and that for compound 3 was discussed as an example (Figure ). It shows two main steps of weight loss. The weight loss from 25 to 180 °C corresponds to the release of the water molecules. The observed weight loss of 9.2% is close to the calculated value (10.2%). The second step covers a temperature range of 180−450 °C, during which the TC4AS and Phen ligands are combusted. The total weight loss at 700 °C is about 89.25%, and the final products are not identified. However, we suggest the residual is mainly composed of CuSO4 and CuO. The weight loss during the decomposition seems similar for all three compounds.

elements.content: The emission spectra of 1−3 in the solid state recorded at room temperature are depicted in Figure . Free C4AS and TC4AS ligands also fluoresce in the solid state with emission peaks at 441 and 427 nm upon excitation at 352 nm, respectively, which may be attributed to the intraligand π*−π transition (Figure , inset). According to the previous report, the emission peaks for the free Phen in the solid state are at 365 and 388 nm (λex = 310 nm), so the Phen ligands almost have no contribution to the fluorescent emission of as-synthesized polymers. As shown in Figure , complexes 1 and 2 exhibit similar broad emission bands with one blue-shift (ca. 420 nm) emission peak and one red-shift (ca. 465 nm) emission peak upon excitation at 348 nm, which might be caused by the π···π interactions between the ligands. The different relative intensities of the peaks at 420 and 465 nm for 1 and 2 may be due to the significant difference of their topological structures and different coordination of the ligands. The emission peak position of 3 is similar to that of free TC4AS, which can also be attributed to intraligand fluorescent emission. These observations indicate that compounds 1−3 may be candidates for blue-light photoactive materials, since these condensed materials are thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The emission spectra of 1-3 in the solid state recorded at room temperature are depicted in Figure . Free C4AS and TC4AS ligands also fluoresce in the solid state with emission peaks at 441 and 427 nm upon excitation at 352 nm, respectively, which may be attributed to the intraligand π*-π transition (Figure , inset). According to the previous report, the emission peaks for the free Phen in the solid state are at 365 and 388 nm (λex = 310 nm), so the Phen ligands almost have no contribution to the fluorescent emission of as-synthesized polymers. As shown in Figure , complexes 1 and 2 exhibit similar broad emission bands with one blue-shift (ca. 420 nm) emission peak and one red-shift (ca. 465 nm) emission peak upon excitation at 348 nm, which might be caused by the π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the ligands. The different relative intensities of the peaks at 420 and 465 nm for 1 and 2 may be due to the significant difference of their topological structures and different coordination of the ligands. The emission peak position of 3 is similar to that of free TC4AS, which can also be attributed to intraligand fluorescent emission. These observations indicate that compounds 1-3 may be candidates for blue-light photoactive materials, since these condensed materials are thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.

elements.content: With the use of two water-soluble calix[4]arenes ligands, p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene (C4AS) and p-sulfonatothiacalix[4]arene (TC4AS), three novel 3D supramolecular networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Two compounds (1 and 2) exhibiting different colors and shapes are found to cocrystallize in a one-pot reaction. It is worth noticing that the CAS molecules can be used as a polydentate ligand to coordinate copper ions in different modes. Furthermore, the auxiliary ligand Phen adopts a chelating mode providing supramolecular interaction (π−π stacking and hydrogen-bonding) sites for molecular recognition in the assembly of complexes 1−3, especially in linking low-dimensional entities into high-dimensional supramolecular frameworks. The successful preparation of these different complexes (1−5) provides a valuable approach for the construction of other different coordination polymers with the introduction of CAS ligands. Subsequent work will be focused on the construction of novel polymers by reacting CAS and other ligands with more metal ions under different conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

With the use of two water-soluble calix[4]arenes ligands, p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene (C4AS) and p-sulfonatothiacalix[4]arene (TC4AS), three novel 3D supramolecular networks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Two compounds (1 and 2) exhibiting different colors and shapes are found to cocrystallize in a one-pot reaction. It is worth noticing that the CAS molecules can be used as a polydentate ligand to coordinate copper ions in different modes. Furthermore, the auxiliary ligand Phen adopts a chelating mode providing supramolecular interaction (π-π stacking and hydrogen-bonding) sites for molecular recognition in the assembly of complexes 1-3, especially in linking low-dimensional entities into high-dimensional supramolecular frameworks. The successful preparation of these different complexes (1-5) provides a valuable approach for the construction of other different coordination polymers with the introduction of CAS ligands. Subsequent work will be focused on the construction of novel polymers by reacting CAS and other ligands with more metal ions under different conditions.

A suspension of CuCl2 (0.2 mmol), Phen (0.2 mmol), and C4AS (0.1 mmol) in water (10 mL) was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (20 mL) and heated to 130 °C in 100 min. The autoclave was kept at 130 °C for 3 days and then slowly cooled to 20 °C at about 4 °C/h. Green prism single crystals of 1 and blue block single crystals of 2 were carefully separated under a microscope and collected for X-ray diffraction determination and other measurements. Yield: ∼10% for 1 and 25% for 2 with respect to calixarene.

Green block single crystals of complex 3 were obtained by the reaction of CuCl (0.1 mmol), Phen (0.2 mmol), and TC4AS (0.1 mmol) in 10 mL of water under the same hydrothermal conditions as those for the syntheses of 1 and 2. Yield: ∼20% with respect to calixarene.

cln_elements.content:
The TGA curves of the title compounds 1−3 are similar, and that for compound 3 was discussed as an example (Figure ). It shows two main steps of weight loss. The weight loss from 25 to 180 °C corresponds to the release of the water molecules. The observed weight loss of 9.2% is close to the calculated value (10.2%). The second step covers a temperature range of 180−450 °C, during which the TC4AS and Phen ligands are combusted. The total weight loss at 700 °C is about 89.25%, and the final products are not identified. However, we suggest the residual is mainly composed of CuSO4 and CuO. The weight loss during the decomposition seems similar for all three compounds.

Photoluminescent Properties

The emission spectra of 1−3 in the solid state recorded at room temperature are depicted in Figure . Free C4AS and TC4AS ligands also fluoresce in the solid state with emission peaks at 441 and 427 nm upon excitation at 352 nm, respectively, which may be attributed to the intraligand π*−π transition (Figure , inset). According to the previous report, the emission peaks for the free Phen in the solid state are at 365 and 388 nm (λex = 310 nm), so the Phen ligands almost have no contribution to the fluorescent emission of as-synthesized polymers. As shown in Figure , complexes 1 and 2 exhibit similar broad emission bands with one blue-shift (ca. 420 nm) emission peak and one red-shift (ca. 465 nm) emission peak upon excitation at 348 nm, which might be caused by the π···π interactions between the ligands. The different relative intensities of the peaks at 420 and 465 nm for 1 and 2 may be due to the significant difference of their topological structures and different coordination of the ligands. The emission peak position of 3 is similar to that of free TC4AS, which can also be attributed to intraligand fluorescent emission. These observations indicate that compounds 1−3 may be candidates for blue-light photoactive materials, since these condensed materials are thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.

(a) ORTEP diagram showing the coordination environment for a tetranuclear Cu unit in 1 with H atoms and the isolated water molecular omitted for clarity. (b) 2-D layered network of 1 formed by π···π stacking and H-bonding (blue dotted lines, π···π stacking interactions; yellow dotted lines, H-bonding interactions; the same hereafter). (c) O−H···O interactions between two adjacent layers along the b axis (up) and the detailed O···O distances in 1 (down) (H atoms omitted for clarity). (d) Schematic drawing of 2-D layer with 44 net (left) and the 3D α-Po-related supramolecular topology in 1 (node, tetranuclear unit; blue line, interaction A; yellow line, interaction B).

(b) 2-D layered network of 1 formed by π⋅⋅⋅π stacking and H-bonding (blue dotted lines, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions; yellow dotted lines, H-bonding interactions; the same hereafter). (c) O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between two adjacent layers along the b axis (up) and the detailed O⋅⋅⋅O distances in 1 (down) (H atoms omitted for clarity). (d) Schematic drawing of 2-D layer with 44 net (left) and the 3D α-Po-related supramolecular topology in 1 (node, tetranuclear unit; blue line, interaction A; yellow line, interaction B).

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Cu cations in 2. (b) View of the 2-D structure of 2 showing the π···π stacking interactions (A and B) between the zigzag chains. The adjacent chains are illustrated in purple and yellow, respectively. (c) H-bonding interactions between the layers (the detail interactions highlighted). (d) Schematic drawing of 2-D layer and 3-D supramolecular topology in 2. A: 63 net (left) and the 3-D topology (right). B: 44 net (left) and the corresponding 3-D topology (right).
